remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example finds a `FORM` object using its name, and submits its data to the server programmatically. The code example requires that your application hosts a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser> control named `webBrowser1`.

remarks.format:
## Remarks While the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlElement.Id%2A> property of an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlElement> must be unique, multiple elements can use the same <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlElement.Name%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Gets an item from the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlElementCollection> objects are read-only. To add an element to an HTML document, use methods such as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlElement.InsertAdjacentElement%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlElement.AppendChild%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: Default Public ReadOnly Property Item(index As Integer) As HtmlElement
public: property System::Windows::Forms::HtmlElement ^ default[int] { System::Windows::Forms::HtmlElement ^ get(int index); };

Docs.param: The position from which to retrieve an item from the collection.
Docs.summary: Gets an item from the collection by specifying its numerical index.
Docs.value: An item from the collection by specifying its numerical index.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Elements in an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlElementCollection> are not guaranteed to be in source code order. In other words, just because a `DIV` element is the first element inside of a `BODY` tag does not mean that the first element of the collection will be the `DIV` element.
